Uncertainty Principle for Communication Compression in Distributed and Federated Learning and the Search for an Optimal Compressor

Mher Safaryan   Egor Shulgin111Part of this work was done by the author as a student at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia.   Peter Richtárik
XXX
King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
(26 / 1 / 2021)
Abstract

In order to mitigate the high communication cost in distributed and federated learning, various vector compression schemes, such as quantization, sparsification and dithering, have become very popular. In designing a compression method, one aims to communicate as few bits as possible, which minimizes the cost per communication round, while at the same time attempting to impart as little distortion (variance) to the communicated messages as possible, which minimizes the adverse effect of the compression on the overall number of communication rounds. However, intuitively, these two goals are fundamentally in conflict: the more compression we allow, the more distorted the messages become. We formalize this intuition and prove an uncertainty principle for randomized compression operators, thus quantifying this limitation mathematically, and effectively providing asymptotically tight lower bounds on what might be achievable with communication compression. Motivated by these developments, we call for the search for the optimal compression operator. In an attempt to take a first step in this direction, we consider an unbiased compression method inspired by the Kashin representation of vectors, which we call Kashin compression (KC). In contrast to all previously proposed compression mechanisms, KC enjoys a dimension independent variance bound for which we derive an explicit formula even in the regime when only a few bits need to be communicate per each vector entry.

1 Introduction

In the quest for high accuracy machine learning models, both the size of the model and consequently the amount of data necessary to train the model have been hugely increased over time (Schmidhuber, 2015; Vaswani u. a., 2019). Because of this, performing the learning process on a single machine is often infeasible. In a typical scenario of distributed learning, the training data (and possibly the model as well) is spread across different machines and thus the process of training is done in a distributed manner (Bekkerman u. a., 2011; Vogels u. a., 2019). Another scenario, most common to federated learning (Konečný u. a., 2016; McMahan u. a., 2017; Karimireddy u. a., 2019a), is when training data is inherently distributed across a large number of mobile edge devices due to data privacy concerns.

1.1 Communication bottleneck

In all cases of distributed learning and federated learning, information (e.g. current stochastic gradient vector or current state of the model) communication between computing nodes is inevitable, which forms the primary bottleneck of such systems (Zhang u. a., 2017; Lin u. a., 2018). This issue is especially apparent in federated learning, where computing nodes are devices with essentially inferior power and the network bandwidth is considerably slow (Li u. a., 2019).

There are two general approaches to address/tackle this problem. One line of research dedicated to so-called local methods suggests to do more computational work before each communication in the hope that those would increase the worth/impact/value of the information to be communicated (Goyal u. a., 2017; Wangni u. a., 2018; Stich, 2018; Khaled u. a., 2020). An alternative approach investigates inexact/lossy information compression strategies which aim to send approximate but relevant information encoded with less number of bits. In this work we focus on the second approach of compressed learning. Research in this latter stream splits into two orthogonal directions. To explore savings in communication, various (mostly randomized) compression operators have been proposed and analyzed such as random sparsification (Konečný und Richtárik, 2018; Wangni u. a., 2018), Top-k𝑘k sparsification (Alistarh u. a., 2018), standard random dithering (Goodall, 1951; Roberts, 1962; Alistarh u. a., 2017), natural dithering (Horváth u. a., 2019a), ternary quantization (Wen u. a., 2017), and sign quantization (Karimireddy u. a., 2019b; Bernstein u. a., 2018, 2019; Liu u. a., 2019; Safaryan und Richtárik, 2019). Table 1 summarizes the most common compression methods with their variances and the number of encoding bits.

In designing a compression operator, one aims to (i) encode the compressed information with as few bits as possible, which minimizes the cost per communication round, and (ii) introduce as little noise (variance) to the communicated messages as possible, which minimizes the adverse effect of the compression on the overall iteration complexity.

1.2 Compressed learning

In order to utilize these compression methods efficiently, a lot of research has been devoted to the study of learning algorithms with compressed communication. Obviously, the presence of compression in a learning algorithm affects the training process and since compression operator encodes the original information approximately, it should be anticipated to increase the number of communication rounds. Table 2 highlights four gradient-type compressed learning algorithms with their corresponding setup and iteration complexity:

  • (i)

    distributed Gradient Descent (GD) with compressed gradients (Khirirat u. a., 2018),

  • (ii)

    distributed Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) with gradient quantization and compression variance reduction (Horváth u. a., 2019b),

  • (iii)

    distributed SGD with bi-directional gradient compression (Horváth u. a., 2019a), and

  • (iv)

    distributed SGD with gradient compression and twofold error compensation (Tang u. a., 2019).

In all cases, the iteration complexity depends on the variance of the underlying compression scheme and grows as more compression is applied. For this reason, we are interested in compression methods which save in communication by using less bits and minimize iteration complexity by introducing lower variance. However, intuitively and also evidently from Table 1, these two goals are in fundamental conflict, i.e. requiring fewer bits to be communicated in each round introduces higher variance, and demanding small variance forces more bits to be communicated.

1.3 Contributions

We make the following contributions in this work:

Uncertainty Principle. We formalize this intuitive trade-off and prove an uncertainty principle for randomized compression operators, which quantifies this limitation mathematically with the inequality

α⋅4b/d≥1,⋅𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑1\alpha\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1, (1)

where α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] is the normalized variance (or contraction factor) associated with the compression operator (Definition 1), b𝑏b is the number of bits required to encode the compressed vector and d𝑑d is the dimension of the vector to be compressed. It is a universal property of compressed communication, completely independent of the optimization algorithm and the problem that distributed training is trying to solve. We visualize this principle in Figure 1, where many possible combinations of parameters α𝛼\alpha and b/d𝑏𝑑\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}} were computed for various compression methods. The dashed red line, indicating the lower bound (1), bounds all possible combinations of all compression operators, thus validating the obtained uncertainty principle for randomized compression operators. We also show that this lower bound is asymptotically tight.

Kashin Compression. Motivated by this principle, we then focus on the search for the optimal compression operator. In an attempt to take a first step in this direction, we investigate an unbiased compression operator inspired by Kashin representation of vectors (Kashin, 1977), which we call Kashin Compression (KC). In contrast to all previously proposed compression methods, KC enjoys a dimension independent variance bound even in a severe compression regime when only a few bits per coordinate can be communicated. We derive an explicit formula for the variance bound. Furthermore, we experimentally observed the superiority of KC in terms of communication savings and stabilization property when compared against commonly used compressors proposed in the literature. In particular, Figure 1 justifies that KC combined with Top-k𝑘k sparsification and dithering operators yields a compression method which is the most efficient scheme when communication is scarce. Kashin’s representation has been used heuristically in the context of federated learning (Caldas u. a., 2019) to mitigate the communication cost. We believe KC should be of high interest in federated and distributed learning.

2 Uncertainty principle for compression operators

In general, an uncertainty principle refers to any type of mathematical inequality expressing some fundamental trade-off between two measurements. The classical Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle in quantum mechanics (Heisenberg, 1927) shows the trade-off between the position and momentum of a particle. In harmonic analysis, the uncertainty principle limits the localization of values of a function and its Fourier transform at the same time (Havin und Jöricke, 1994). Alternatively in the context of signal processing, signals cannot be simultaneously localized in both time domain and frequency domain (Gabor, 1946). The uncertainty principle in communication deals with the quite intuitive trade-off between information compression (encoding bits) and approximation error (variance), namely more compression forces heavier distortion to communicated messages and tighter approximation requires less information compression.

In this section, we present our UP for communication compression revealing the trade-off between encoding bits of compressed information and the variance produced by compression operator. First, we describe UP for some general class of biased compressions. Afterwards, we specialize it to the class of unbiased compressions.

2.1 UP for biased compressions

We work with the class of biased compression operators which are contractive.

Definition 1 (Biased Compressions)

Let 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) be the class of biased (and possibly randomized) compression operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] contractive property, i.e. for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖22]≤α​‖x‖22.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥22𝛼superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑥22\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|_{2}^{2}. (2)

The parameter α𝛼\alpha can be seen as the normalized variance of the compression operator. Note that the compression 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} does not need to be randomized to belong to this class. For instance, Top-k𝑘k sparsification operator satisfies (2) without the expectation for α=1−kd𝛼1𝑘𝑑\alpha=1-\frac{k}{d}. Next, we formalize uncertainty principle for the class 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Theorem 1

Let 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} be any compression operator from 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) and b𝑏b be the total number of bits needed to encode the compressed vector 𝒞​(x)𝒞𝑥\mathcal{C}(x) for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Then the following form of uncertainty principle holds

α⋅4b/d≥1.⋅𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑1\alpha\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1. (3)

One can view the binary32 and binary64 floating-points formats as biased compression methods for the actual real numbers (i.e. d=1𝑑1d=1), using only 32 and 64 bits respectively to represent a single number. Intuitively, these formats have their precision (i.e. α𝛼\sqrt{\alpha}) limits and the uncertainty principle (3) shows that the precision cannot be better than 2−32superscript2322^{-32} for binary32 format and 2−64superscript2642^{-64} for binary64 format. Thus, any floating-point format representing a single number with r𝑟r bits has precision constraint of 2−rsuperscript2𝑟2^{-r}, where the base 222 stems from the binary nature of the bit.

Furthermore, notice that compression operators can achieve zero variance in some settings, e.g. ternary or scaled sign quantization when d=1𝑑1d=1 (see Table 1). On the other hand, the UP (3) implies that the normalized variance α>0𝛼0\alpha>0 for any finite bits b𝑏b. The reason for this inconsistency comes from the fact that, for instance, the binary32 format encodes any number with 32 bits and the error 2−32superscript2322^{-32} is usually ignored in practice. We can adjust UP to any digital format, using r𝑟r bits per single number, as

(α+4−r)​4b/d≥1.𝛼superscript4𝑟superscript4𝑏𝑑1\left(\alpha+4^{-r}\right)4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1. (4)

2.2 UP for unbiased compressions

We now specialize (3) to the class of unbiased compressions. First, we recall the definition of unbiased compression operators with a given variance.

Definition 2 (Unbiased Compressions)

Denote by 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega) the class of unbiased compression operators 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with variance ω>0𝜔0\omega>0, that is, for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

𝔼​[𝒞​(x)]=x,𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)−x‖22]≤ω​‖x‖22.formulae-sequence𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑥𝑥𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥22𝜔superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑥22\textstyle\mathbb{E}\left[\mathcal{C}(x)\right]=x,\qquad\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\omega\|x\|_{2}^{2}. (5)

To establish an uncertainty principle for 𝒞∈𝕌​(ω)𝒞𝕌𝜔{\cal C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega), we show that all unbiased compression operators with the proper scaling factor are included in 𝔹​(α)𝔹𝛼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Lemma 1

If 𝒞∈𝕌​(ω)𝒞𝕌𝜔\mathcal{C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega), then 1ω+1​𝒞∈𝔹​(ωω+1)1𝜔1𝒞𝔹𝜔𝜔1\tfrac{1}{\omega+1}\mathcal{C}\in\mathbb{B}(\tfrac{\omega}{\omega+1}).

Using this inclusion, we can apply Theorem 1 to the class 𝕌​(ω)𝕌𝜔\mathbb{U}(\omega) and derive an uncertainty principle for unbiased compression operators.

Theorem 2

Let 𝒞:ℝd→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} be any unbiased compression operator with variance ω≥0𝜔0\omega\geq 0 and b𝑏b be the total number of bits needed to encode the compressed vector 𝒞​(x)𝒞𝑥\mathcal{C}(x) for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. Then the uncertainty principle takes the form

ωω+1⋅4b/d≥1.⋅𝜔𝜔1superscript4𝑏𝑑1\frac{\omega}{\omega+1}\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1. (6)

3 Compression with polytopes

Here we describe an unbiased compression scheme based on polytopes. With this particular compression we illustrate that it is possible for unbiased compressions to have dimension independent variance bounds and at the same time communicate a single bits per coordinate.

Let x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be nonzero vector that we need to encode. First, we project the vector on the unit sphere

𝕊d−1={x∈ℝd:‖x‖2=1},superscript𝕊𝑑1conditional-set𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑subscriptnorm𝑥21\mathbb{S}^{d-1}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\|x\|_{2}=1\},

thus separating the magnitude ‖x‖2∈ℝsubscriptnorm𝑥2ℝ\|x\|_{2}\in\mathbb{R} from the direction x/‖x‖2∈𝕊d−1𝑥subscriptnorm𝑥2superscript𝕊𝑑1x/\|x\|_{2}\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}. The magnitude is a dimension independent scalar value and we can transfer it cheaply, say by 32 bits. To encode the unit vector x/‖x‖2𝑥subscriptnorm𝑥2x/\|x\|_{2} we approximate the unit sphere by polytopes and then randomize over the vertices of the polytope. Polytopes can be seen as generalizations of planar polygons in high dimensions. Formally, let Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} be a polytope with vertices {v1,v2,…,vm}⊂ℝdsubscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2…subscript𝑣𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑\{v_{1},v_{2},\dots,v_{m}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} such that it contains the unit sphere, i.e. 𝕊d−1⊂Pmsuperscript𝕊𝑑1subscript𝑃𝑚\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\subset P_{m}, and all vertices are on the sphere of radius R>1𝑅1R>1. Then, any unit vector v∈𝕊d−1𝑣superscript𝕊𝑑1v\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1} can be expressed as a convex combination ∑k=1mwk​vksuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑚subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑣𝑘\sum_{k=1}^{m}w_{k}v_{k} with some non-negative weights wk=wk​(x)subscript𝑤𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘𝑥w_{k}=w_{k}(x). Equivalently, v𝑣v can be expressed as an expectation of a random vector over vksubscript𝑣𝑘v_{k} with probabilities wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}. Therefore, the direction x/‖x‖2𝑥subscriptnorm𝑥2x/\|x\|_{2} could be encoded with roughly log⁡m𝑚\log m bits and the variance ω𝜔\omega of compression will depend on the approximation, more specifically ω=R2−1𝜔superscript𝑅21\omega=R^{2}-1. In Kochol (2004, 1994) it is given a constructive proof on approximation of the d𝑑d-dimensional unit sphere by polytopes with m≥2​d𝑚2𝑑m\geq 2d vertices for which ω=𝒪​(dlog⁡m/d)𝜔𝒪𝑑𝑚𝑑\omega={\cal O}\left(\tfrac{d}{\log\nicefrac{{m}}{{d}}}\right). So, choosing the number of vertices to be m=2d𝑚superscript2𝑑m=2^{d}, one gets an unbiased compression operator with 𝒪​(1)𝒪1{\cal O}(1) variance (independent of dimension d𝑑d) and with 1 bit per coordinate encoding.

This simple method does not seem to be practical as 2dsuperscript2𝑑2^{d} vertices of the polytope either need to be stored or computed each time they are used, which is infeasible for large dimensions. However, we use this construction and show that lower bounds (6) and hence (3) are asymptotically tight.

Theorem 3

For any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 there exists an unbiased compression 𝒞:𝕊d−1→ℝd:𝒞→superscript𝕊𝑑1superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} of some dimension d𝑑d and variance ω>0𝜔0\omega>0 such that

ωω+1​4b/d<1+ϵ,𝜔𝜔1superscript4𝑏𝑑1italic-ϵ\frac{\omega}{\omega+1}4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}<1+\epsilon, (7)

where b𝑏b is the number of bits to encode 𝒞​(x)∈ℝd𝒞𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}(x)\in\mathbb{R}^{d} for any x∈𝕊d−1𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑1x\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}.

4 Compression with Kashin’s representation

In this section we review the notion of Kashin’s representation, the algorithm in Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010) on computing it efficiently and then describe the quantization step.

4.1 Representation systems

The most common way of compressing a given vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is to use its orthogonal representation with respect to the standard basis (ei)i=1dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑒𝑖𝑖1𝑑(e_{i})_{i=1}^{d} in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}:

x=∑i=1dxi​ei,xi=⟨x,ei⟩.formulae-sequence𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑥subscript𝑒𝑖x=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{d}x_{i}e_{i},\qquad x_{i}=\left\langle x,e_{i}\right\rangle.

However, the restriction of orthogonal expansions is that coefficients xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} are independent in the sense that if we lost one of them, then we cannot recover it even approximately. Furthermore, each coefficient xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} may carry very different portion of the total information that vector x𝑥x contains; some coefficients may carry more information than others and thus be more sensitive to compression.

For this reason, it is preferable to use tight frames and frame representations instead. Tight frames are generalizations of orthonormal bases, where the system of vectors are not required to be linearly independent. Formally, vectors (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑖1𝐷(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} form a tight frame if any vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} admits a frame representation

x=∑i=1Dai​ui,ai=⟨x,ui⟩.formulae-sequence𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖𝑥subscript𝑢𝑖x=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}a_{i}u_{i},\qquad a_{i}=\left\langle x,u_{i}\right\rangle. (8)

Clearly, if D>d𝐷𝑑D>d (the case we are interested in), then the system (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑖1𝐷(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} is linearly dependent and hence the representation (8) with coefficients aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} is not unique. The idea is to exploit this redundancy and choose coefficients aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} in such a way to spread the information uniformly among these coefficients. However, the frame representation may not distribute the information well enough. Thus, we need a particular representation for which coefficients aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} have smallest possible dynamic range.

For a frame (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑖1𝐷(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} define the d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D frame matrix U𝑈U by stacking frame vectors uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} as columns. It can be easily seen that being a tight frame is equivalent to frame matrix to be orthogonal, i.e. U​U⊤=Id𝑈superscript𝑈topsubscript𝐼𝑑UU^{\top}=I_{d}, where Idsubscript𝐼𝑑I_{d} is the d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d identity matrix. Using the frame matrix U𝑈U, frame representation (8) takes the form x=U​a𝑥𝑈𝑎x=Ua.

Definition 3 (Kashin’s representation)

Let (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑖1𝐷(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} be a tight frame in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. Define Kashin’s representation of x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with level K𝐾K the following expansion

x=∑i=1Dai​ui,max1≤i≤D⁡|ai|≤KD​‖x‖2.formulae-sequence𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷subscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖subscript1𝑖𝐷subscript𝑎𝑖𝐾𝐷subscriptnorm𝑥2x=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}a_{i}u_{i},\qquad\max\limits_{1\leq i\leq D}|a_{i}|\leq\frac{K}{\sqrt{D}}\|x\|_{2}. (9)

Optimality. As noted in (Lyubarskii und Vershynin, 2010), Kashin’s representation has the smallest possible dynamic range K/D𝐾𝐷\nicefrac{{K}}{{\sqrt{D}}}, which is d𝑑\sqrt{d} times smaller then dynamic range of the frame representation (8).

Existence. It turns out that not every tight frame can guarantee Kashin’s representation with constant level. The following existence result is based on Kashin’s theorem (Kashin, 1977):

Theorem 4 (Kashin (1977))

There exist tight frames in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} with arbitrarily small redundancy λ=D/d>1𝜆𝐷𝑑1\lambda=\nicefrac{{D}}{{d}}>1, and such that every vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} admits Kashin’s representation with level K=K​(λ)𝐾𝐾𝜆K=K(\lambda) that depends on λ𝜆\lambda only (not on d𝑑d or D𝐷D).

4.2 Computing Kashin’s representation

To compute Kashin’s representation we use the algorithm developed in Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010), which transforms the frame representation (8) into Kashin’s representation (9). The algorithm requires tight frame with frame matrix satisfying the restricted isometry property:

Definition 4 (Restricted Isometry Property (RIP))

A given d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D matrix U𝑈U satisfies the Restricted Isometry Property with parameters δ,η∈(0,1)𝛿𝜂01\delta,\eta\in(0,1) if for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

|supp​(x)|≤δ​D⇒‖U​x‖2≤η​‖x‖2.formulae-sequencesupp𝑥𝛿𝐷⇒subscriptnorm𝑈𝑥2𝜂subscriptnorm𝑥2\textstyle|{\rm supp}(x)|\leq\delta D\quad\Rightarrow\quad\|Ux\|_{2}\leq\eta\|x\|_{2}. (10)

In general, for an orthogonal d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D matrix U𝑈U we can only guarantee the inequality ‖U​x‖2≤‖x‖2subscriptnorm𝑈𝑥2subscriptnorm𝑥2\|Ux\|_{2}\leq\|x\|_{2} if x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. The RIP requires U𝑈U to be a contraction mapping for sparse x𝑥x. With a frame matrix satisfying RIP, the analysis of Algorithm 1 from (Lyubarskii und Vershynin, 2010) yields a formula for the level of Kashin’s representation:

Theorem 5 (see Theorem 3.5 of Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010))

Let (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝑖1𝐷(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} be a tight frame in ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} which satisfies RIP with parameters δ,η𝛿𝜂\delta,\eta. Then any vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} admits a Kashin’s representation with level

K=1δ​(1−η).𝐾1𝛿1𝜂K=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\delta}(1-\eta)}. (11)

4.3 Quantizing Kashin’s representation

We utilize Kashin’s representation to design a compression method, which will enjoy dimension-free variance bound on the approximation error. Let x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be the vector that we want to communicate and λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 be the redundancy factor so that D=λ​d𝐷𝜆𝑑D=\lambda d is positive integer. First we find Kashin’s representation of x𝑥x, i.e. x=U​a𝑥𝑈𝑎x=Ua for some a∈ℝD𝑎superscriptℝ𝐷a\in\mathbb{R}^{D}, and then quantize coefficients aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} using any unbiased compression operator 𝒞:ℝD→ℝD:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝐷superscriptℝ𝐷{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{D}\to\mathbb{R}^{D} that preserves the sign and maximum magnitude:

0≤𝒞​(a)​sign(a)≤‖a‖∞,a∈ℝD.formulae-sequence0𝒞𝑎sign𝑎subscriptnorm𝑎𝑎superscriptℝ𝐷\textstyle 0\leq{\cal C}(a)\operatorname*{{\rm sign}}(a)\leq\|a\|_{\infty},\quad a\in\mathbb{R}^{D}. (12)

For example, ternary quantization or any dithering (standard random, natural) can be applied. The vector that we communicate is the quantized coefficients 𝒞​(a)∈ℝD𝒞𝑎superscriptℝ𝐷\mathcal{C}(a)\in\mathbb{R}^{D} and KC is defined via

𝒞κ​(x)=U​𝒞​(a).subscript𝒞𝜅𝑥𝑈𝒞𝑎{\cal C}_{\kappa}(x)=U{\cal C}(a).

Due to unbiasedness of 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} and linearity of expectation, we preserve unbiasedness for 𝒞κsubscript𝒞𝜅{\cal C}_{\kappa}:

𝔼​[𝒞κ​(x)]=𝔼​[U​𝒞​(a)]=U​𝔼​[𝒞​(a)]=U​a=x.𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝒞𝜅𝑥𝔼delimited-[]𝑈𝒞𝑎𝑈𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑎𝑈𝑎𝑥\textstyle\mathbb{E}[{\cal C}_{\kappa}(x)]=\mathbb{E}\left[U{\cal C}(a)\right]=U\mathbb{E}\left[{\cal C}(a)\right]=Ua=x.

Then the error of approximation can be bounded uniformly (without the expectation) as follows

‖𝒞κ​(x)−x‖22=‖U​𝒞​(a)−U​a‖22≤‖𝒞​(a)−a‖22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒞𝜅𝑥𝑥22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑈𝒞𝑎𝑈𝑎22superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒞𝑎𝑎22\displaystyle\|{\cal C}_{\kappa}(x)-x\|_{2}^{2}=\|U{\cal C}(a)-Ua\|_{2}^{2}\leq\|{\cal C}(a)-a\|_{2}^{2} ≤\displaystyle\leq Dmax1≤i≤D(𝒞(a)i−ai)2\displaystyle D\max_{1\leq i\leq D}({\cal C}(a)_{i}-a_{i})^{2}
≤\displaystyle\leq D​‖a‖∞2≤D​(K​(λ)D​‖x‖2)2=K2​(λ)​‖x‖22.𝐷superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑎2𝐷superscript𝐾𝜆𝐷subscriptnorm𝑥22superscript𝐾2𝜆superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑥22\displaystyle D\|a\|_{\infty}^{2}\leq D\left(\frac{K(\lambda)}{\sqrt{D}}\|x\|_{2}\right)^{2}=K^{2}(\lambda)\|x\|_{2}^{2}.

The obtained uniform upper bound K​(λ)2𝐾superscript𝜆2K(\lambda)^{2} does not depend on the dimension d𝑑d. It depends only on the redundancy factor λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 which should be chosen depending on how less we want to communicate. Thus, KC 𝒞κsubscript𝒞𝜅{\cal C}_{\kappa} with any unbiased quantization (12) belongs to 𝕌​(K2​(λ))𝕌superscript𝐾2𝜆\mathbb{U}\left(K^{2}(\lambda)\right).

Described Kashin representation and Kashin compression has similarities with the Atomo framework Wang u. a. (2018), which is a general sparsification method applied on any atomic decomposition. In particular, Kashin representation x=U​a𝑥𝑈𝑎x=Ua can be viewed as an atomic decomposition of x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in lifted space ℝDsuperscriptℝ𝐷\mathbb{R}^{D}. However, in contrast to Atomo framework, we do not apply sparsification afterwards as it violates the condition (12). Instead, we utilize quantizers (e.g. coordinate-wise quantization operators) to satisfy (12), which ensures uniform and dimension-free upper bound for the variance.

5 Measure concentration and orthogonal matrices

The concentration of the measure is a remarkable high-dimensional phenomenon which roughly claims that a function defined on a high-dimensional space and having small oscillations takes values highly concentrated around the average (Ledoux, 2001; Giannopoulos und Milman, 2000). Here we present one example of such concentration for Lipschitz functions on the unit sphere, which will be the key to justify the restricted isometry property.

5.1 Concentration on the sphere for Lipschitz functions

We say that f:𝕊d−1→ℝ:𝑓→superscript𝕊𝑑1ℝf\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R} is a Lipschitz function with constant L>0𝐿0L>0 if for any x,y∈𝕊d−1𝑥𝑦superscript𝕊𝑑1x,\,y\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}

|f​(x)−f​(y)|≤L​‖x−y‖2.𝑓𝑥𝑓𝑦𝐿subscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2|f(x)-f(y)|\leq L\|x-y\|_{2}.

The following result is a reformulation of Theorem 5.1.4 in Vershynin (2018) with explicit absolute constants.

Theorem 6

Let X∈𝕊d−1𝑋superscript𝕊𝑑1X\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1} be a random vector uniformly distributed on the unit Euclidean sphere. If f:𝕊d−1→ℝ:𝑓→superscript𝕊𝑑1ℝf\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R} is L−limit-from𝐿L-Lipschitz function, then for any t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0

Prob​(|f​(X)−𝔼​f​(X)|≥t)≤5​exp⁡(−(d−2)​t28​L2).Prob𝑓𝑋𝔼𝑓𝑋𝑡5𝑑2superscript𝑡28superscript𝐿2{\rm Prob}\left(|f(X)-\mathbb{E}f(X)|\geq t\right)\leq 5\exp\left(-\frac{(d-2)t^{2}}{8L^{2}}\right).

Informally and rather surprisingly, Lipschitz functions on a high-dimensional unit sphere are almost constants. Particularly, it implies that deviations of function values from the average are at most 8​Ld8𝐿𝑑\frac{8L}{\sqrt{d}} with confidence level more than 0.99. We will apply this concentration inequality for the function x→‖U​x‖2→𝑥subscriptnorm𝑈𝑥2x\to\|Ux\|_{2} which is 1−limit-from11-Lipschitz if U𝑈U is orthogonal.

5.2 Random orthogonal matrices

Up to this point we did not discuss how to choose the frame vectors uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} or the frame matrix U𝑈U, which is used in the construction of Kashin’s representation. We only know that it should be orthogonal and satisfy RIP for some parameters δ,η𝛿𝜂\delta,\eta. We now describe how to construct frame matrix U𝑈U and how to estimate parameters δ,η𝛿𝜂\delta,\eta. Unluckily, there is no an explicit construction scheme for such matrices. There are random generation processes that provide probabilistic guarantees (Candès und Tao, 2005, 2006; Lyubarskii und Vershynin, 2010).

Consider random d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D matrices with orthonormal rows. Such matrices are obtained from selecting the first d𝑑d rows of orthogonal D×D𝐷𝐷D\times D matrices. Let O​(D)𝑂𝐷O(D) be the space of all orthogonal D×D𝐷𝐷D\times D matrices with the unique translation invariance and normalized measure, which is called Haar measure for that space. Then the space of d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D orthogonal matrices is

O​(d×D)={U=Pd​V:V∈O​(D)},𝑂𝑑𝐷conditional-set𝑈subscript𝑃𝑑𝑉𝑉𝑂𝐷O(d\times D)=\{U=P_{d}V\colon V\in O(D)\},

where Pd:ℝD→ℝd:subscript𝑃𝑑→superscriptℝ𝐷superscriptℝ𝑑P_{d}\colon\mathbb{R}^{D}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is the orthogonal projection on the first d𝑑d coordinates. The probability measure on O​(d×D)𝑂𝑑𝐷O(d\times D) is induces by the Haar measure on O​(D)𝑂𝐷O(D). Next we show that, with respect to the normalized Haar measure, randomly generated orthogonal matrices satisfy RIP with high probability. The following result is refinement of Theorem 4.1 in Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010).

Theorem 7

Let λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 and D=λ​d𝐷𝜆𝑑D=\lambda d, then with probability at least

1−5​exp⁡[−d​(λ−1)2​(126+1208​log⁡(1−1λ))],15𝑑superscript𝜆12126120811𝜆1-5\exp\left[-d\left(\sqrt{\lambda}-1\right)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{26}+\frac{1}{208}\log\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{\lambda}}\right)\right)\right],

a random orthogonal d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D matrix U𝑈U satisfies RIP with parameters

η=34+14⋅1λ,δ=154​(1−1λ)2.formulae-sequence𝜂34⋅141𝜆𝛿1superscript54superscript11𝜆2\eta=\frac{3}{4}+\frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{\lambda}},\qquad\delta=\frac{1}{5^{4}}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{\lambda}}\right)^{2}. (13)

Note that the expression for the probability can be negative if λ𝜆\lambda is too close to 1. Specifically, the logarithmic term vanishes for λ≈1.0005𝜆1.0005\lambda\approx 1.0005 giving negative probability. However, the probability approaches to 111 quite rapidly for bigger λ𝜆\lambda’s. To get a sense of how high that probability can be, note that for d=1000𝑑1000d=1000 variables and λ=2𝜆2\lambda=2 inflation it is bigger than 0.980.980.98.

Now that we have explicit formulas for the parameters δ𝛿\delta and η𝜂\eta, we can combine it with the results of Section 4 and summarize with the following theorem.

Theorem 8

Let λ>1𝜆1\lambda>1 be the redundancy factor and 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} be any unbiased compression operator satisfying (12). Then Kashin Compression 𝒞κ∈𝕌​(ωλ)subscript𝒞𝜅𝕌subscript𝜔𝜆{\cal C}_{\kappa}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega_{\lambda}) is an unbiased compression with dimension independent variance

ωλ=(10​λλ−1)4.subscript𝜔𝜆superscript10𝜆𝜆14\omega_{\lambda}=\left(\frac{10\sqrt{\lambda}}{\sqrt{\lambda}-1}\right)^{4}. (14)

6 Experiments

In this section we describe the implementation details of KC and present our experiments of KC compared to other popular compression methods in the literature.

6.1 Implementation details of KC

To generate a random (fat) orthogonal frame matrix U𝑈U, we first generate a random matrix with entries drown independently from Gaussian distribution. Then we extract an orthogonal matrix by applying QR decomposition. Note that, for big dimensions the generation process of frame matrix U𝑈U becomes computationally expensive. However, after fixing the dimension of to-be-compressed vectors then the frame matrix needs to be generated only once and can be used throughout the learning process.

Afterwards, we turn to the estimation of the parameters δ𝛿\delta and η𝜂\eta of RIP, which are necessary to compute Kashin’s representations. These parameters are estimated iteratively so to minimize the representation level K𝐾K (11) subject to the constraint (10) of RIP. For fixed δ𝛿\delta we first find the least η𝜂\eta such 10 holds for unit vectors, which were obtained by normalizing Gaussian random vectors (we chose sample size of 104−105superscript104superscript10510^{4}-10^{5}, which provided a good estimate). Then we tune the parameter δ𝛿\delta (initially chosen 0.90.90.9) to minimize the level K𝐾K (11).

6.2 Empirical variance comparison

We empirically compare the variance produced by natural dithering (Horváth u. a., 2019a) against KC with natural dithering and observe that latter introduces much less variance. We generated n𝑛n vectors with d𝑑d independent entries from standard Gaussian distribution. Then we fix the minimum number of levels s𝑠s that allows obtaining an acceptable variance for performing KC with natural dithering. Next, we adjust levels s𝑠s for natural dithering to the almost same number of bits used for transmission of the compressed vector. For each of these vectors we compute normalized empirical variance via

ω​(x)≔‖𝒞​(x)−x‖2‖x‖2.≔𝜔𝑥superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥𝑥2superscriptnorm𝑥2\omega(x)\coloneqq\frac{\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}}{\|x\|^{2}}. (15)

In Figure 2 we provide boxplots for empirical variances, which show that the increase of parameter λ𝜆\lambda leads to smaller variance for KC. They also confirm that for natural dithering, the variance ω𝜔\omega scales with the dimension d𝑑d while for KC that scaling is significantly reduced (see also Table 1 for variance bounds). This shows the positive effect of KC combined with other compression methods. For additional insights, we present also swarmplots provided by Seaborn Library. Figure 3 illustrates the strong robustness property of KC with respect to outliers.

6.3 Minimizing quadratics with CGD

To illustrate the advantages of KC in optimization algorithms, we minimized randomly generated quadratic functions (16) for d=104𝑑superscript104d=10^{4} using gradient descent with compressed gradients.

minx∈ℝd⁡f​(x)=12​x⊤​A​x−b⊤​x,subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑥12superscript𝑥top𝐴𝑥superscript𝑏top𝑥\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}~{}~{}f(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}Ax-b^{\top}x, (16)

In Figure 4(a) we evaluate functional suboptimality

f​(xk)−f∗f​(x0)−f∗𝑓subscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑓𝑓subscript𝑥0superscript𝑓\frac{f(x_{k})-f^{*}}{f(x_{0})-f^{*}}

in log-scale for vertical axis. These plots illustrate the superiority of KC with ternary quantization, where it does not degrade the convergence at all and saves in communication compared to other compression methods and without any compression scheme.

To provide more insights into this setting, Figure 4(b) visualizes empirical variances of the compressed gradients throughout the optimization process, revealing both the low variance feature and the stabilization property of KC.

6.4 Minimizing quadratics with distributed CGD

Consider the minimization problem of the average of n𝑛n quadratics

minx∈ℝd⁡f​(x)≔1n​∑i=1nfi​(x),wherefi​(x)=12​x⊤​Ai​x,formulae-sequence≔subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑥1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥wheresubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥12superscript𝑥topsubscript𝐴𝑖𝑥\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x),\qquad\text{where}\qquad f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}A_{i}x, (17)

with synthetically generated matrices Aisubscript𝐴𝑖A_{i}. We solve this problem with Distributed Compressed Gradient Descent (Algorithm 2) using a selection of compression operators.

Figures 5 and 6 show that KC combined with ternary quantization leads to faster convergence and uses less bits to communicate than ternary quantization alone. Note that in higher dimension the gap between KC with ternary quantization and no compression gets smaller in the iteration plot, while in the communication plot it gets bigger. So, in high dimensions KC convergences slightly worse than no compression scheme, but the savings in communication are huge.

A.2 Proof of Theorem 1: Derivation from Rate Distortion Theory

After the first online appearance of the work, we had been aware of by an anonymous reviewer that this result follows from the rate distortion theory. We include the derivation here.

Here we deduce the lower bound (3) from the results of rate distortion theory, which is a subfield of information theory (Cover und Thomas, 2006). Rate distortion theory describes theoretical limitations of lossy compression of a given random variable in terms of information rate R𝑅R and distortion threshold D𝐷D. In our notation, the rate R=b/d𝑅𝑏𝑑R=\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}} is the average number of bits over coordinates and distortion D=α​σ2𝐷𝛼superscript𝜎2D=\alpha\sigma^{2}, where σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} is the variance of the random variable. Rate distortion function R​(D)𝑅𝐷R(D) of a given random source is the minimal rate to transfer an i.i.d. sample such that the receiver can decode the initial sequence with distortion D𝐷D. We assume that squared error distortion measure is used, namely

ρ​(x,x^)=1d​∑i=1d(xi−x^i)2.𝜌𝑥^𝑥1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript^𝑥𝑖2\rho(x,\hat{x})=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{i=1}^{d}(x_{i}-\hat{x}_{i})^{2}.

This distortion measure is particularly convenient for our setup as inequality (2) can be written as

𝔼𝒞​[ρ​(𝒞​(x),x)]≤α​ρ​(x,0),x∈ℝd.formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼𝒞delimited-[]𝜌𝒞𝑥𝑥𝛼𝜌𝑥0𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[\rho({\cal C}(x),x)\right]\leq\alpha\rho(x,0),\quad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (21)

If (21) holds uniformly for any x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, then it also holds in expectation with respect to x∼𝒟similar-to𝑥𝒟x\sim{\cal D} with i.i.d. coordinates sampled from some distribution 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}:

𝔼𝒞,𝒟​[ρ​(𝒞​(x),x)]≤α​𝔼𝒟​[ρ​(x,0)]=α​σ2=D,x∼𝒟.formulae-sequencesubscript𝔼𝒞𝒟delimited-[]𝜌𝒞𝑥𝑥𝛼subscript𝔼𝒟delimited-[]𝜌𝑥0𝛼superscript𝜎2𝐷similar-to𝑥𝒟\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C},{\cal D}}\left[\rho({\cal C}(x),x)\right]\leq\alpha\mathbb{E}_{{\cal D}}\left[\rho(x,0)\right]=\alpha\sigma^{2}=D,\quad x\sim{\cal D}.

This implies that the rate R𝑅R of compression 𝒞𝒞{\cal C} is bigger than rate distortion function R​(D)𝑅𝐷R(D) for any distribution 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}. In particular, R≥R𝒩​(D)𝑅subscript𝑅𝒩𝐷R\geq R_{{\cal N}}(D) when distribution 𝒟𝒟{\cal D} is Gaussian. It is known that rate distortion function R𝒩​(D)subscript𝑅𝒩𝐷R_{\mathcal{N}}(D) for Gaussian random variable can be written analytically as

R𝒩​(D)={log4⁡σ2Dif0≤D≤σ20ifD>σ2.subscript𝑅𝒩𝐷casessubscript4superscript𝜎2𝐷if0𝐷superscript𝜎20if𝐷superscript𝜎2R_{{\cal N}}(D)=\begin{cases}\log_{4}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{D}&\text{if}\quad 0\leq D\leq\sigma^{2}\\ 0&\text{if}\quad D>\sigma^{2}.\end{cases}

Translating inequality R≥R𝒩​(D)𝑅subscript𝑅𝒩𝐷R\geq R_{{\cal N}}(D) into the language of α=D/σ2∈[0,1]𝛼𝐷superscript𝜎201\alpha=\nicefrac{{D}}{{\sigma^{2}}}\in[0,1] and b=R​d𝑏𝑅𝑑b=Rd, we get α⋅4b/d≥1⋅𝛼superscript4𝑏𝑑1\alpha\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1.

It is worth to mention that Gaussian random variable is the hardest source to encode, meaning it requires the most number of bits to ensure a given distortion constraint. Formally, for any random variable with the same σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} variance the rate distortion function R​(D)≤R𝒩​(D)𝑅𝐷subscript𝑅𝒩𝐷R(D)\leq R_{{\cal N}}(D).

Remark 1

In practice we do not deal with too large or too small values because of the finite bit representation of a single float in a machine. Therefore, the quantifier ∀x∈ℝdfor-all𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in (2) or (21) and the idealized Gaussian source used for the lower bound should be relaxed by excluding vectors with too small or too large norms and considering approximate Gaussian distributions.

A.3 Proof of Lemma 1

Let 𝒞∈𝕌​(ω)𝒞𝕌𝜔\mathcal{C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega). Using relations 𝔼​[𝒞​(x)]=x𝔼delimited-[]𝒞𝑥𝑥\mathbb{E}\left[{\cal C}(x)\right]=x and 𝔼​[‖𝒞​(x)‖2]≤(ω+1)​‖x‖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒞𝑥2𝜔1superscriptnorm𝑥2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{\cal C}(x)\right\|^{2}\right]\leq(\omega+1)\|x\|^{2}, we get

B.1 Proof of Theorem 3: Asymptotic tightness of UP

We use the construction of Kochol (1994), which states the following:

Theorem 9 (Kochol (1994))

For any dimension d≥1𝑑1d\geq 1 and any fixed 2​d≤m≤2d2𝑑𝑚superscript2𝑑2d\leq m\leq 2^{d} there exist m𝑚m unit vectors such that the convex hull of them (or the polytope with such vertices) contains a ball of radius

c1​1d​log⁡md,subscript𝑐11𝑑𝑚𝑑c_{1}\sqrt{\frac{1}{d}\log\frac{m}{d}},

for some absolute constant c1>0subscript𝑐10c_{1}>0.

Fix c∈(0,1)𝑐01c\in(0,1) and d≥d0𝑑subscript𝑑0d\geq d_{0} where d0=d0​(c)subscript𝑑0subscript𝑑0𝑐d_{0}=d_{0}(c) is the smallest possible d𝑑d such that 2​d≤2c​d2𝑑superscript2𝑐𝑑2d\leq 2^{cd}. Choose m=2c​d𝑚superscript2𝑐𝑑m=2^{cd} be the number of vertices of the polytope obtained by inversing (with respect to the unit sphere) the m𝑚m unit vectors from Theorem 9. Clearly, 2​d≤m≤2d2𝑑𝑚superscript2𝑑2d\leq m\leq 2^{d} as d≥d0𝑑subscript𝑑0d\geq d_{0}. Therefore, the obtained polytope contains the unit ball Bd​(0,1)superscript𝐵𝑑01B^{d}(0,1) and vertices have the same magnitude R𝑅R satisfying

1<R≤1c1​dlog⁡md.1𝑅1subscript𝑐1𝑑𝑚𝑑1<R\leq\frac{1}{c_{1}}\sqrt{\frac{d}{\log\frac{m}{d}}}.

This construction yields an ω𝜔\omega-compressor 𝒞:𝕊d−1→ℝd:𝒞→superscript𝕊𝑑1superscriptℝ𝑑{\cal C}\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with b=c​d𝑏𝑐𝑑b=cd bits and

ω+1=R2≤1c12⋅dlog⁡md=1c12⋅dc​d−log⁡d.𝜔1superscript𝑅2⋅1superscriptsubscript𝑐12𝑑𝑚𝑑⋅1superscriptsubscript𝑐12𝑑𝑐𝑑𝑑\omega+1=R^{2}\leq\frac{1}{c_{1}^{2}}\cdot\frac{d}{\log\frac{m}{d}}=\frac{1}{c_{1}^{2}}\cdot\frac{d}{cd-\log d}.

ωω+1⋅4b/d=(1−1ω+1)⋅4b/d≤(1−c12​(c−log⁡dd))​4c.⋅𝜔𝜔1superscript4𝑏𝑑⋅11𝜔1superscript4𝑏𝑑1superscriptsubscript𝑐12𝑐𝑑𝑑superscript4𝑐\frac{\omega}{\omega+1}\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}=\left(1-\frac{1}{\omega+1}\right)\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\leq\left(1-c_{1}^{2}\left(c-\frac{\log d}{d}\right)\right)4^{c}. (22)

Notice that choosing small c→0→𝑐0c\to 0 and large d→∞→𝑑d\to\infty we can make the right hand side of (22) arbitrarily close to 1.

Appendix C Proofs for Section 5

Proofs presented in this section are adjustments of several standard and classical techniques. We present the proofs here to find out hidden absolute constants.

C.1 Proof of Theorem 6: Concentration on the sphere for Lipschitz functions

Let 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1} be the unit sphere with the normalized Lebesgue measure μ𝜇\mu and the geodesic metric dist(x,y)=arccos⁡⟨x,y⟩dist𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦\operatorname*{{\rm dist}}(x,y)=\arccos\langle x,y\rangle representing the angle between x𝑥x and y𝑦y. Using this metric, we define the spherical caps as the balls in 𝕊d−1superscript𝕊𝑑1\mathbb{S}^{d-1}:

Ba​(r)={x∈𝕊d−1:dist(x,a)≤r},a∈𝕊d−1,r>0.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐵𝑎𝑟conditional-set𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑1dist𝑥𝑎𝑟formulae-sequence𝑎superscript𝕊𝑑1𝑟0B_{a}(r)=\{x\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\colon\operatorname*{{\rm dist}}(x,a)\leq r\},\quad a\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1},\,r>0.

For a set A⊂𝕊d−1𝐴superscript𝕊𝑑1A\subset\mathbb{S}^{d-1} and non-negative number t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0 denote by A​(t)𝐴𝑡A(t) the t𝑡t-neighborhood of A𝐴A with respect to geodesic metric:

A​(t)={x∈𝕊d−1:dist(x,A)≤t}.𝐴𝑡conditional-set𝑥superscript𝕊𝑑1dist𝑥𝐴𝑡A(t)=\left\{x\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\colon\operatorname*{{\rm dist}}(x,A)\leq t\right\}.

The famous result of P. Levy on isoperimetric inequality for the sphere states that among all subsets A⊂𝕊d−1𝐴superscript𝕊𝑑1A\subset\mathbb{S}^{d-1} of a given measure, the spherical cap has the smallest measure for the neighborhood (see e.g. (Ledoux, 2001)).

Theorem 10 (Levy’s isoperimetric inequality)

Let A⊂𝕊d−1𝐴superscript𝕊𝑑1A\subset\mathbb{S}^{d-1} be a closed set and let t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0. If B=Ba​(r)𝐵subscript𝐵𝑎𝑟B=B_{a}(r) is a spherical cap with μ​(A)=μ​(B)𝜇𝐴𝜇𝐵\mu(A)=\mu(B), then

μ​(A​(t))≥μ​(B​(t))≡μ​(Ba​(r+t)).𝜇𝐴𝑡𝜇𝐵𝑡𝜇subscript𝐵𝑎𝑟𝑡\mu\left(A(t)\right)\geq\mu\left(B(t)\right)\equiv\mu(B_{a}(r+t)).

We also need the following well known upper bound on the measure of spherical caps

Lemma 2

Let t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0. If B⊂𝕊d−1𝐵superscript𝕊𝑑1B\subset\mathbb{S}^{d-1} is a spherical cap with radius π/2−t𝜋2𝑡\pi/2-t, then

μ​(B)≤π8​exp⁡(−(d−2)​t22).𝜇𝐵𝜋8𝑑2superscript𝑡22\mu(B)\leq\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{8}}\exp\left(-\frac{(d-2)t^{2}}{2}\right). (23)

These two results yield a concentration inequality on the unit sphere around median of the Lipschitz function.

Theorem 11

Let f:𝕊d−1→ℝ:𝑓→superscript𝕊𝑑1ℝf\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R} be a L𝐿L-Lipschitz function (w.r.t. geodesic metric) and let M=Mf𝑀subscript𝑀𝑓M=M_{f} be its median, i.e.

μ​{x:f​(x)≥M}≥12andμ​{x:f​(x)≤M}≥12.formulae-sequence𝜇conditional-set𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑀12and𝜇conditional-set𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑀12\mu\left\{x\colon f(x)\geq M\right\}\geq\frac{1}{2}\quad\text{and}\quad\mu\left\{x\colon f(x)\leq M\right\}\geq\frac{1}{2}.

Then, for any t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0

μ​{x:|f​(x)−M|≥t}≤π2​exp⁡(−(d−2)​t22​L2).𝜇conditional-set𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑀𝑡𝜋2𝑑2superscript𝑡22superscript𝐿2\mu\left\{x\colon|f(x)-M|\geq t\right\}\leq\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}\exp\left(-\frac{(d-2)t^{2}}{2L^{2}}\right). (24)
Remark 2

Notice that Lipschitzness w.r.t. geodesic metric is weaker than w.r.t. Euclidean metric. This implies that the obtained concentration holds for L𝐿L-Lipschitz function w.r.t. standard Euclidean distance.

Continuity of μ𝜇\mu and f𝑓f give the result with the relaxed inequality.

C.2 Proof of Theorem 7: Random orthogonal matrices with RIP

Most of the proof follows the steps of the proof of Theorem 4.1 of Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010). First, we relax the inequality in Theorem 6 to

Prob​(|f​(X)−𝔼​f​(X)|≥t)≤5​exp⁡(−d​t29​L2),t≥0,d≥20.formulae-sequenceProb𝑓𝑋𝔼𝑓𝑋𝑡5𝑑superscript𝑡29superscript𝐿2formulae-sequence𝑡0𝑑20{\rm Prob}\left(|f(X)-\mathbb{E}f(X)|\geq t\right)\leq 5\exp\left(-\frac{d\,t^{2}}{9L^{2}}\right),\quad t\geq 0,\,d\geq 20. (26)

Let x∈𝕊D−1𝑥superscript𝕊𝐷1x\in\mathbb{S}^{D-1} be fixed. Any orthogonal d×D𝑑𝐷d\times D matrix U∈O​(d×D)𝑈𝑂𝑑𝐷U\in O(d\times D) can be represented as the projection U=Pd​V𝑈subscript𝑃𝑑𝑉U=P_{d}V of D×D𝐷𝐷D\times D orthogonal matrix V∈O​(D)𝑉𝑂𝐷V\in O(D). The uniform probability measure (or Haar measure) on O​(D)𝑂𝐷O(D) ensures that if V∈O​(D)𝑉𝑂𝐷V\in O(D) is random then the vector z=V​x𝑧𝑉𝑥z=Vx is uniformly distributed on 𝕊D−1superscript𝕊𝐷1\mathbb{S}^{D-1}. Therefore, if U∈O​(d×D)𝑈𝑂𝑑𝐷U\in O(d\times D) is random with respect to the induced Haar measure on O​(d×D)𝑂𝑑𝐷O(d\times D), then random vectors U​x𝑈𝑥Ux and Pd​zsubscript𝑃𝑑𝑧P_{d}z have identical distributions. Denote f​(z)=‖Pd​z‖2𝑓𝑧subscriptnormsubscript𝑃𝑑𝑧2f(z)=\|P_{d}z\|_{2} and notice that f𝑓f is 111-Lipschitz on the sphere 𝕊D−1superscript𝕊𝐷1\mathbb{S}^{D-1}. To apply the concentration inequality (26), we compute the expected norm of these random vectors:

𝔼​f​(z)𝔼𝑓𝑧\displaystyle\mathbb{E}f(z) ≤\displaystyle\leq (∫𝕊D−1‖Pd​z‖22​𝑑μ​(z))1/2=(∑i=1d∫𝕊D−1zi2​𝑑μ​(z))1/2=(∑i=1d1D)1/2=dD,superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝕊𝐷1superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑃𝑑𝑧22differential-d𝜇𝑧12superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝕊𝐷1superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖2differential-d𝜇𝑧12superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑1𝐷12𝑑𝐷\displaystyle\left(\int_{\mathbb{S}^{D-1}}\|P_{d}z\|_{2}^{2}\,d\mu(z)\right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{d}\int_{\mathbb{S}^{D-1}}z_{i}^{2}\,d\mu(z)\right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}=\left(\sum_{i=1}^{d}\frac{1}{D}\right)^{\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{d}{D}},

where we used the fact that coordinates zi2superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑖2z_{i}^{2} are distributed identically and therefore they have the same 1/D1𝐷\nicefrac{{1}}{{D}} mean. Applying inequality (26) yields, for any t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0

Prob(U∈O(d×D):∥Ux∥2>d/D+t)\displaystyle{\rm Prob}\left(U\in O(d\times D)\colon\|Ux\|_{2}>\sqrt{\nicefrac{{d}}{{D}}}+t\right) ≤\displaystyle\leq Prob(z∈𝕊D−1:|f(z)−𝔼f(z)|>t)\displaystyle{\rm Prob}\left(z\in\mathbb{S}^{D-1}\colon|f(z)-\mathbb{E}f(z)|>t\right) (27)
≤\displaystyle\leq 5​exp⁡(−D​t29).5𝐷superscript𝑡29\displaystyle 5\exp\left(-\frac{Dt^{2}}{9}\right).

Let Sδsuperscript𝑆𝛿S^{\delta} be the set of vectors x∈𝕊D−1𝑥superscript𝕊𝐷1x\in\mathbb{S}^{D-1} with at most δ​D𝛿𝐷\delta D non-zero elements

Sδ:={x∈𝕊D−1:|supp​(x)|≤δ​D}=⋃|I|≤δ​D{x∈𝕊D−1:supp​(x)⊆I}=⋃|I|≤δ​DSIδ,assignsuperscript𝑆𝛿conditional-set𝑥superscript𝕊𝐷1supp𝑥𝛿𝐷subscript𝐼𝛿𝐷conditional-set𝑥superscript𝕊𝐷1supp𝑥𝐼subscript𝐼𝛿𝐷subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛿𝐼S^{\delta}:=\left\{x\in\mathbb{S}^{D-1}\colon|{\rm supp}(x)|\leq\delta D\right\}=\bigcup_{|I|\leq\delta D}\left\{x\in\mathbb{S}^{D-1}\colon{\rm supp}(x)\subseteq I\right\}=\bigcup_{|I|\leq\delta D}S^{\delta}_{I},

where SIδsubscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛿𝐼S^{\delta}_{I} denotes the subset of vectors Sδsuperscript𝑆𝛿S^{\delta} having a given support I⊆[D]𝐼delimited-[]𝐷I\subseteq[D] of indices. Fix ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. For each I𝐼I, we can find an ε𝜀\varepsilon-net for SIδsubscriptsuperscript𝑆𝛿𝐼S^{\delta}_{I} in the Euclidean norm with cardinality at most (3/ε)δ​Dsuperscript3𝜀𝛿𝐷\left(\nicefrac{{3}}{{\varepsilon}}\right)^{\delta D} (see Proposition 4.2.12 and Corollary 4.2.13 in (Vershynin, 2018)). Prob(U∈O(d×D):∥Uy∥2>d/D+t, for some y∈𝒩ε)≤|𝒩ε|⋅5exp(−D​t29).{\rm Prob}\left(U\in O(d\times D)\colon\|Uy\|_{2}>\sqrt{\nicefrac{{d}}{{D}}}+t,\,\text{ for some }\,y\in\mathcal{N}_{\varepsilon}\right)\leq|\mathcal{N}_{\varepsilon}|\cdot 5\exp\left(-\frac{Dt^{2}}{9}\right). (29)

Since 𝒩εsubscript𝒩𝜀\mathcal{N}_{\varepsilon} is an ε𝜀\varepsilon-net for Sδsuperscript𝑆𝛿S^{\delta}, then for any x∈Sδ𝑥superscript𝑆𝛿x\in S^{\delta} there exists such y∈𝒩ε𝑦subscript𝒩𝜀y\in\mathcal{N}_{\varepsilon} that ‖x−y‖2≤εsubscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2𝜀\|x-y\|_{2}\leq\varepsilon. Furthermore, from the orthogonality of matrix U𝑈U we conclude

‖U​x‖2≤‖U​y‖2+‖U​(x−y)‖2≤‖U​y‖2+ε.subscriptnorm𝑈𝑥2subscriptnorm𝑈𝑦2subscriptnorm𝑈𝑥𝑦2subscriptnorm𝑈𝑦2𝜀\|Ux\|_{2}\leq\|Uy\|_{2}+\|U(x-y)\|_{2}\leq\|Uy\|_{2}+\varepsilon.

The above inequality can be reformulated in terms of RIP condition for a random matrix U∈O​(d×D)𝑈𝑂𝑑𝐷U\in O(d\times D)

Thus, recalling the formula (11) for the level K𝐾K, we aim to choose such ε,t,δ𝜀𝑡𝛿\varepsilon,t,\delta (depending on λ𝜆\lambda) that to maximize both 1/K1𝐾\nicefrac{{1}}{{K}} and the probability in (30), i.e. the following two expressions

Note that choosing parameters ε,t,δ𝜀𝑡𝛿\varepsilon,t,\delta is not trivial in this case as we want to maximize both terms and there is a trade-off between them. We choose the parameters as follows (these expressions were constructed using two techniques: solving optimality conditions for the Lagrangian and numerical simulations.)

C.3 Proof of Theorem 8: Kashin Compression

The unbiasedness of 𝒞κsubscript𝒞𝜅{\cal C}_{\kappa} has been shown in part 4.3 with uniform upper bound K​(λ)2𝐾superscript𝜆2K(\lambda)^{2} for the variance. To prove the formula (14) we use expressions (33)

ωλ=K​(λ)2=(1δ​(1−η))2=(14​ε⋅25​ε)2=(110​ε)4=(10​λλ−1)4.subscript𝜔𝜆𝐾superscript𝜆2superscript1𝛿1𝜂2superscript1⋅4𝜀25𝜀2superscript110𝜀4superscript10𝜆𝜆14\omega_{\lambda}=K(\lambda)^{2}=\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{\delta}(1-\eta)}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{1}{4\varepsilon\cdot 25\varepsilon}\right)^{2}=\left(\frac{1}{10\varepsilon}\right)^{4}=\left(\frac{10\sqrt{\lambda}}{\sqrt{\lambda}-1}\right)^{4}.
